docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Rust is a general-purpose programming language emphasizing performance, type safety, and concurrency. It enforces memory safety, meaning that all references point to valid memory. It does so without a traditional garbage collector; instead, memory safety errors and data races are prevented by the "borrow checker", which tracks the object lifetime of references at compile time. -- wikipedia

docs.title: What will we do in this tutorial
docs.text:
• Setting up a DevContainer for Rust.
  • Writing a simple "Hello COMP423" program.
  • Compiling and running the program.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before You Begin

Ensure the following prerequisites are met before starting the setup process:

  • Installed Software:
    • Visual Studio Code
    • VS Code Remote - Containers plugin.
    • Git installed locally.
  • GitHub Account: You need access to GitHub to create repositories and collaborate.

docs.title: Setting Up the Git Repository
docs.text:
Follow these steps to initialize a Git repository for your project:

  1. Create a folder for your project:

    Create a directory for your project with a meaningful name (e.g., hello-comp423-rust) and navigate into it.

    mkdir hello-comp423-rust
cd hello-comp423-rust

  2. Initialize a new Git repository:

    git init

  3. Add a .gitignore file:

    Create a .gitignore file at the root of your project to ignore unnecessary files like Rust build artifacts.

    echo "target/" >> .gitignore

  4. Create a new repository on GitHub and link it:

    Set up a remote repository on GitHub, and connect it to your local project.

    git remote add origin https://github.com/yourusername/hello-comp423-rust.git

  5. Push your initial commit:

    Create a README.md file, commit your changes, and push them to the remote repository.

    echo "# Rust DevContainer Project" > README.md
git add README.md
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git push -u origin main

docs.title: What is .gitignore?
docs.text: The .gitignore file specifies which files or directories Git should ignore. For Rust projects, ignoring the target/ directory is crucial because it contains compiled binaries and temporary files, which are unnecessary for version control. Learn more about .gitignore.

docs.title: Configuring the DevContainer
docs.text:
• Explain how to configure the development container for Rust:

    1. Create a .devcontainer folder:

      mkdir .devcontainer
cd .devcontainer
touch devcontainer.json

    2. Write the devcontainer.json:

      {
    "name": "Rust DevContainer",
    "image": "mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/rust:latest",
    "customizations": {
    "vscode": {
        "extensions": [
        "rust-lang.rust-analyzer"
        ]
    }
    }
}

  • Install Rust Analyzer on VSCode:

    • This extension provides support for the Rust programming language. It is recommended over and replaces rust-lang.rust.

docs.title: What is a container
docs.text: • A standard package of software—known as a container—bundles an application’s code together with the related configuration files and libraries, and with the dependencies required for the app to run. This allows developers and IT pros to deploy applications seamlessly across environments.

docs.title: How to Start a DevContainer
docs.text:
When you open your project directory in VS Code, a prompt should appear asking if you want to reopen the folder in a DevContainer: - Click "Reopen in Container". If the prompt does not appear, you can manually start the DevContainer:

  1. Open the command palette using Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (Mac).
  2. Search for and select "Reopen in Container".
  3. VS Code will automatically pull the required Docker image and start the container.

docs.title: Verifying Rust Version
docs.text:
• Run the following commands to check if Rust is installed properly:

    rustc --version 
cargo --version

  • You should see:

    rustc 1.83.0 (90b35a623 2024-11-26)
cargo 1.83.0 (5ffbef321 2024-10-29)

docs.title: Creating your first project
docs.text:
• Cargo new

    cargo new hello_comp423 --vcs none
cd hello_comp423

  • cargo new creates a simple Hello World project with a main.rs source code file and Cargo.toml Cargo manifest file.

    src\
    main.rs
Cargo.toml

  • --vcs none: preventsCargo from automatically creating a Git repository.

docs.title: Compiling and Running the Program
docs.text:
• cargo run: Run a binary or example of the local package.

    $cargo run
Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.01s
Running `target/debug/hello_comp423`
Hello COMP423!

  • cargo build: Compile local packages and all of their dependencies.

    $cargo build
Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.06s
